sen.j: 中御門 宣胤（なかのみかど のぶたね、嘉吉2年（1442年） - 大永5年11月17日 (旧暦)（1525年12月1日））は、室町時代中期から戦国時代 (日本)にかけての公卿である。
sen.e: Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO (born 1442, died November 17, 1525 (old lunar calendar) (December 1, 1525)) was a court noble from the middle of Muromachi Period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO (born 1442, died November 17, 1525 (old lunar calendar - December 1, 1525) was a court noble from the middle of Muromachi Period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).
Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO (1442 - December 11, 1525) was a court noble from the middle of Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦にしました。

sen.j: 藤原北家勧修寺流中御門家当主。
sen.e: He was the head of the Nakanomikado family of the Kajuji line of Fujiwara North Household.
He was the head of the Nakanomikado family of the Kajuji line of Fujiwara North Household.
He was the head of the Nakanomikado family of the Kajuji line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 出家後の戒名は乗光。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name after becoming a priest was Joko.
His posthumous Buddhist name after becoming a priest was Joko.
His posthumous Buddhist name after becoming a priest was Joko.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 嘉吉2年（1442年）、権大納言中御門明豊の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as a son of Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) Akitoyo NAKAMIKADO in 1442.
He was born as the son of Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) Akitoyo NAKAMIKADO in 1442.
He was born as the son of Gon Dainagon (a provisional chief councilor of state) Akitoyo NAKAMIKADO in 1442.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 翌年数え年2歳にして叙爵。
sen.e: In the following year, he was ennobled in his 2nd year.
The following year, he was ennobled in his 2nd year.
The following year, he conferred a peerage in his second year.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 文安5年（1448年）従五位上・右衛門佐に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In 1448, he was appointed to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), Uemon no suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards).
In 1448, he was appointed to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), Uemon no suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards).
In 1448, he was appointed to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), Uemon no suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards).

sen.j: 康正元年（1455年）正五位上弁官・蔵人所、翌年に右中弁に進み、以後朝廷の実務に携わる。
sen.e: He was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) Jobenkan (major controller of oversight department) at Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office) in 1455, and then to Uchuben (Middle Controller of the Right) in the following year; since then, he was involved in practical works for the Imperial court.

He was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) Jobenkan (major controller of oversight department) at Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office) in 1455, and then to Uchuben (Middle Controller of the Right) in the following year; since then, he was involved in practical work for the Imperial court.

He was promoted to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) Jobenkan (major controller of oversight department) at Kurodo dokoro (the Office of Imperial Household Logistics) in 1455, and then to Uchuben (Middle Controller of the Right) in the following year; since then, he was involved in practical work for the Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 寛正2年（1461年）には後花園天皇の蔵人頭、同5年（1464年）後土御門天皇の蔵人頭となっている。
sen.e: He served Emperor Gohanazono as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) in 1461, and then served Emperor Gotsuchimikado as Kurodo no to in 1464.
He served Emperor Gohanazono as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) in 1461, and then served Emperor Gotsuchimikado as Kurodo no to in 1464.
He served Emperor Gohanazono as Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) in 1461, and then served Emperor Gotsuchimikado as Kurodo no to in 1464.

sen.j: やはり実務派官僚である甘露寺親長の娘を娶った。
sen.e: He married a daughter of Chikanaga KANROJI, who was also a governmental official responsible for practical works.
He married the daughter of Chikanaga KANROJI, who was also a governmental official responsible for practical work.
He married the daughter of Chikanaga KANROJI, who was also a governmental official responsible for practical work.

sen.j: 文正元年（1466年）従三位参議となり公卿に列する。
sen.e: He was promoted to a court noble when he became Jusani (Junior Third Rank) Sangi (councilor) in 1466.
He was promoted to a court noble when he became Jusani (Junior Third Rank) Sangi (councilor) in 1466.
He was promoted to a court noble when he became Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) Sangi (councilor) in 1466.

sen.j: 応仁元年（1467年）に勃発した応仁の乱以来、朝廷儀式の荒廃・形骸化は著しかった。
sen.e: After the outbreak of Onin War in 1467, Imperial court rituals became obsolete and degenerated into a mere facade.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the outbreak of Onin War in 1467, Imperial court rituals became obsolete and degenerated into a mere facade.
After the outbreak of Onin War in 1467, Imperial court rituals became obsolete and degenerated into a mere facade.

sen.j: これを嘆いた宣胤は復興を目指して公卿の長老で有職故実に詳しい一条兼良らから教えを請い、先例を学んで若い公卿らに指導した。
sen.e: Mourning Nobutane aimed at restoration, and learned from Kanera ICHIJO, who was a senior court noble versed in Yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past); he then taught precedents to young court nobles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Mourning Nobutane aimed at restoration, and learned from Kanera ICHIJO, who was a senior court noble versed in Yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past); he then taught precedents to young court nobles.

Mourning Nobutane aimed at restoration, and learned from Kanera ICHIJO, who was a senior court noble versed in Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette); he then taught precedents to young court nobles.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: また、宣胤は書道・和歌にも巧みで、しばしば揮毫を依頼されている。
sen.e: Nobutane was also a skillful calligrapher and poet, and was often asked to conduct kigo (write with a brush).
Nobutane was also a skillful calligrapher and poet, and was often asked to conduct kigo (write with a brush).
Nobutane was also a skillful calligrapher and poet, and was often asked to conduct kigo (write with a brush).

sen.j: 長享2年（1488年）には権大納言に昇進。
sen.e: He was promoted to Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) in 1488.
He was promoted to Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor) in 1488.
He was promoted to Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state) in 1488.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 永正8年（1511年）には従一位に昇るが、その後まもなく出家し、乗光と号する。
sen.e: Soon after he was raised to juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1511, he became a priest and named himself Joko.
Soon after he was raised to juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1511, he became a priest and named himself Joko.
Soon after he was raised to Juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1511, he became a priest and named himself Joko.

sen.j: 大永5年（1525年）に死去。
sen.e: He died in 1525.
He died in 1525.
He died in 1525.

sen.j: 享年84。
sen.e: Died at age 84.
Died at age 84.
Died at the age of 84.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 日記として『宣胤卿記』がある。
sen.e: He left a diary titled "Nobutane-kyo-ki" (the diary of Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO).
He left a diary titled "Nobutane-kyo-ki" (the diary of Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO).
He left a diary titled "Nobutane kyo ki" (the diary of Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO).

sen.j: 子に中御門宣秀、四条隆永らがいる。
sen.e: His children included Nobuhide NAKAMIKADO and Takanaga SHIJO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His children included Nobuhide NAKAMIKADO and Takanaga SHIJO.
His children included Nobuhide NAKAMIKADO and Takanaga SHIJO.

sen.j: また娘の寿桂尼は、今川氏親に嫁ぎ、今川氏輝・今川義元などを生み、孫の今川氏真の後見役を務めるなど影響力が強く、駿河国の女大名と呼ばれた人物である。
sen.e: His daughter Jukei-ni married into Ujichika IMAGAWA, gave birth to Ujiteru IMAGAWA and Yoshimoto IMAGAWA, and served her grandson, Ujizane IMAGAWA, as his conservator; she was highly influential and was given the nickname the female feudal lord of Suruga Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His daughter Jukei-ni married into Ujichika IMAGAWA, gave birth to Ujiteru IMAGAWA and Yoshimoto IMAGAWA, and served her grandson, Ujizane IMAGAWA, as his conservator; she was highly influential and was given the nickname the female feudal lord of Suruga Province.

His daughter Jukeini married into Ujichika IMAGAWA, gave birth to Ujiteru IMAGAWA and Yoshimoto IMAGAWA, and served her grandson, Ujizane IMAGAWA, as his conservator; she was highly influential and was given the nickname the female feudal lord of Suruga Province.
